title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
What is CJ?
In comparative judgment (CJ) studies [1, 2]:


judges assess a specific trait or attribute
across different stimuli
by performing pairwise comparisons
producing a dichotomous outcome



e.g., when assessing writing quality, judges compare pairs of written texts (the stimuli) to determine the relative writing quality each text exhibit (the trait)

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
Is it succesful?
Numerous studies document the method’s effectiveness in assessing traits and competencies. They have focus on three aspects:


Reliability
Validity
Practical applicability

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
Introduction (cont.)
Result on reliability:


CJ needs a modest number of pairwise comparisons [3, 4]
CJ can generate precise and consistent trait scores compared to other assessment methods [5–7].
CJ has equal, if not superior, time efficiency than other assessment methods [8–10].



Third point: when employing adaptive comparison algorithms

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
Introduction (cont.)
Result on *validity:**


CJ scores represent accurately the traits under measurement [7, 11–14].

title: Let’s talk about Thurstone & Co.
text:
Introduction (cont.)
Result on *practical applicability:**


CJ is versatile across both educational and non-educational contexts [14–20].
